user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SymbolLookup_Static:
```c
int32 OS_SymbolLookup_Static(cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName, const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list --
             * Return "OS_ERROR" to indicate that an actual search was done
             * with a not-found result, vs. not searching at all. */
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }
        if (strcmp(StaticSym->Name, SymbolName) == 0 &&
            (ModuleName == NULL || strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0))
        {
            /* found matching symbol */
            *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)StaticSym->Address;
            return_code    = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SymbolLookup_Static:
typedef uintptr_t cpuaddr
...
typedef const struct
{
    const char *Name;
    void (*Address)(void);
    const char *Module;
} OS_static_symbol_record_t
...
#define OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE
...
#define OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED (-28)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in this function. The only write involving a parameter is '*SymbolAddress = ...' which modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter (permitted by Rule 17.8); the pointer variable SymbolAddress itself is not reassigned. The other parameters (SymbolName, ModuleName) are only read (compared via strcmp and checked for NULL) and are not modified. The increment '++StaticSym' modifies a local pointer, not a function parameter. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
